comment:
This game featured a major upset in the U.S. Open. Gabriel Schwartzman is a
very talented young Grandmaster but he runs into a creative sacrifice in this game.

The old Steinitz variation is enjoying renewed popularity these days. A game
between Kasparov and Short at the 1994 Euwe Memorial in Amsterdam had made a
deep impression on me, and I was hoping to make use of a plan involving h4,
Rh3-g3 and a kingside attack that worked well for Kasparov.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2
comment:
The pawn sacrifice offered by this move has rarely been tested in the
tournament arena. I was quite surprised when Schwartzman accepted it.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5
comment:
This was my own idea. 10.Be2 was recommended in an old book by Harding, but it
did not impress me at all. I decided to eliminate the dark-squared bishops and
use Kasparov's attacking formation on the kingside.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6
comment: 13...Qe7 would have made it harder for me to justify the investment of the pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3
comment: This is a very important move. I need to free the knight from the need to hang around at c3 just to defend the poor pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4
comment:
This eliminates the enemy knight, and I have a decent endgame even without the
pawn, because Black is left with a very bad bishop.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3
comment:
There are two points to this move. One is to be ready to transfer to the
kingside at a moment's notice, and the other, more subtle, will be revealed shortly.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6

1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5
comment:
!? 
I hadn't worked out all the tactics here. But I had a great deal of confidence
and had seen some pleasant long variations, beginning at move 27!

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5
comment: This fell in with my plans. But what about the alternative? Could I have held the position following:

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5 23. Rbc3
comment: A critical preparatory move before the real attack begins.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5 23. Rbc3 Qa4
comment: The rest of the game is virtually forced.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5 23. Rbc3 Qa4 24. Qh6 Rf7 25. exf6 g6
comment: Forced, but Black's defenses cannot hold.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5 23. Rbc3 Qa4 24. Qh6 Rf7 25. exf6 g6 26. Rxg6+
comment: !! The rook is sacrificed for two pawns and a tremendous attack.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5 23. Rbc3 Qa4 24. Qh6 Rf7 25. exf6 g6 26. Rxg6+ hxg6 27. Qxg6+ Kf8 28. Qh6+

1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. Nf3 Nc6 7. Be3 Qb6 8. Qd2 Qxb2 9. Rb1 Qa3 10. dxc5 Bxc5 11. Bxc5 Qxc5 12. Bd3 a6 13. h4 Nb6 14. Rh3 Nc4 15. Bxc4 Qxc4 16. a3 b5 17. Ne2 Bd7 18. Nfd4 Nxd4 19. Nxd4 Rc8 20. Rbb3 O-O 21. Rhg3 f6 22. f5 exf5 23. Rbc3 Qa4 24. Qh6 Rf7 25. exf6 g6 26. Rxg6+ hxg6 27. Qxg6+ Kf8 28. Qh6+ Ke8 29. Qh8+ Rf8 30. Re3+ Kd8 31. Qxf8+ Kc7 32. Qc5+ Kb8 33. Qd6+ Rc7 34. Rc3 Qa5 35. Qxc7+
comment: Black resigned, because once the pieces come off, the f-pawn promotes. Black is powerless to prevent it.
